head.title: Silicon Microwire Arrays with Nanoscale Spacing for Radial Junction c-Si Solar Cells with an Efficiency of 20.5% | ACS Nano

meta.content: Silicon Microwire Arrays with Nanoscale Spacing for Radial Junction c-Si Solar Cells with an Efficiency of 20.5%

Structural optimization of microwire arrays is important for the successful demonstration of the practical feasibility of radial junction crystalline silicon (c-Si) solar cells. In this study, we investigated an optimized design of tapered microwire (TMW) arrays to maximize the light absorption of c-Si solar cells, while minimizing the surface recombination, for simultaneously improving the open-circuit voltage and short-circuit current density (Jsc). Finite-difference time-domain simulations confirmed that controlling the spacing between the TMWs at the nanometer scale is more effective for increasing the light absorption than increasing the TMW length. The photogenerated current of a c-Si TMW array with a 200 nm spacing was calculated to be 42.90 mA/cm2, which is close to the theoretical limit of 43.37 mA/cm2 in the 300–1100 nm wavelength range. To experimentally demonstrate the TMW arrays with a nanometer-scale spacing of 200 nm, which cannot be realized by conventional photolithography, we utilized a soft lithography method based on polystyrene beads for patterning a c-Si wafer. The solar cells based on optimized TMW arrays exhibited a Jsc of 42.5 mA/cm2 and power conversion efficiency of 20.5%, which exceed those of the previously reported microwire-based radial junction solar cells.

J

div.span: KEYWORDS:

div.div:
Solar cells based on crystalline silicon (c-Si) account for more than 95% of the solar energy market owing to the abundance of Si in the Earth’s crust and the favorable bandgap (1.12 eV) and excellent long-term stability of Si, which are suitable for developing highly efficient solar cells.
(1)
Over the past decades, numerous studies have aimed at improving the power conversion efficiency (PCE) and decreasing the production cost of c-Si solar cells.
(2−6)
In particular, nanostructured c-Si solar cells are expected to be capable of complete light absorption.
(7−15)
Although nanostructures have excellent light-absorption capabilities, the actual solar cell efficiencies are low.
(16)
Nanostructured c-Si solar cells have a large surface area; consequently, there is significant surface recombination, which adversely affects the device performance. In addition, as we consider the general junction depth of conventional thermal doping, all the nanostructures are fully depleted with a high doping concentration and thus can cause severe Auger recombination, resulting in the degradation of the solar cell efficiency. In contrast to nanostructures, vertical microwire (MW) structures have attracted significant attention because they not only improve light absorption but also enable the formation of a stable radial junction, which significantly decreases the requisite diffusion length of the photoinduced carriers for charge separation.
(17)
This alleviates the need for high-purity c-Si wafers that consume substantial energy in the purification process. However, to realize a highly efficient c-Si MW solar cell, it is necessary to engineer the structure of the vertical MW arrays for maximizing the light absorption by the material.
(18)

The optical characteristics of MW arrays are predominantly governed by their physical dimensions (e.g., diameter, length, and spacing between the wires). The diameter of the MWs determines the overall area of the exposed surface of the MWs, which reflects light on the top surface area.
(19−21)
In general, thinner MWs are beneficial for limiting the reflection of light from the MW surface.
(17)
However, a MW diameter of at least 2 μm would be appropriate for obtaining a stable radial junction, given the junction depth of c-Si.
(17)
Instead, an array of tapered MWs (TMWs) could restrict the surface reflection to less than 2%. Given that the top-surface reflection of light from the MWs is minimized, the total absorption of the incident light would then be determined by the length of the MWs and the spacing between them. Light absorption by the MWs generally tends to increase with an increase in their length, but it no longer increases above the certain length (approximately 20 μm) of the MW.
(20)
Furthermore, as the surface area of MWs increases with an increase in their length, the formation of a conformal surface passivation layer to prevent surface recombination becomes more critical. However, owing to the high aspect ratio of the MWs, it is difficult to conformally passivate their surface. Nonconformal surface passivation may result in severe surface recombination of the photoinduced carriers.
(22)
Moreover, the series resistance is likely to increase owing to the increased travel distance of the carriers from the top to the bottom of a longer MW before they are collected. Therefore, it is necessary to control the spacing between MWs of an appropriate length for maximizing the light absorption.
(18,23)

In the top-down method of c-Si MW fabrication, the MW length can be controlled systematically by changing the etching time. However, it is challenging to decrease the spacing between the MWs to the nanometer scale using conventional photolithography processes.
(24)
In principle, the wavelength of the light source is one of the dominant factors that determine the resolution of photolithography. The most common UV light wavelengths used in conventional photolithography are 436 nm (g-line) and 365 nm (i-line), with each minimum feature size having been reported as being ∼1 μm and ∼350 nm, respectively.
(25)
Due to the patterning resolution of these wavelengths, conventional photolithography is not suitable for controlling the spacing of TMW arrays at the nanometer scale. Meanwhile, soft lithography is an effective alternative method for patterning materials at the nanometer scale. A monolayer of polymer beads can be readily formed via soft lithography, and the diameter and spacing between the beads can be controlled at the nanometer scale via oxygen plasma etching. The optimized pattern of the beads can then be used as an etch mask for forming vertical MW arrays by a reactive ion etching (RIE) process.
(26−29)
In this study, we optimized spacing and length of c-Si TMW arrays consisting of TMWs of 2 μm diameter to maximize the light absorption in the 300–1100 nm wavelength region through finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) simulations. Then, for experimental validation, we fabricated c-Si TMW arrays with optimized spacing and length via soft lithography. As a result, the c-Si TMW arrays fabricated with a length and spacing of 10 μm and 200 nm, respectively, exhibited maximized light absorption of >98.5% in the 300–1000 nm wavelength range. Furthermore, the c-Si TMW solar cells with the optimized design exhibited a PCE of 20.5% with a current density of 42.5 mA/cm
2
. The results of this study indicate that the light absorption as well as the PCE of c-Si TMW solar cells can be improved significantly by optimizing the spacing and length of the MWs.

div.div:
Three-dimensional FDTD (Lumerical) simulations were performed to investigate the variation in the absorption of c-Si according to the length of the TMWs and spacing between them in the c-Si TMW array.
Figure
1
a shows a schematic of the c-Si TMW structure used in the FDTD simulation. Considering the light absorption properties of the TMW arrays, as well as the effective separation of photogenerated carriers through the radial junction, the diameter of the TMWs was fixed at 2 μm.
(17)
In the FDTD simulation, the light absorbed by the c-Si TMW array on a c-Si substrate in the 300–1100 nm wavelength range was calculated by varying the TMW length and interwire spacing. Essentially, the c-Si TMW is an optimized structure developed for solar cells to minimize the surface reflection.
(21)
In general, surface reflection increases with an increase in the difference in the refractive index between the two media (air and Si in this case).
(30,31)
However, at the tip of the c-Si TMW, the filling fraction of c-Si is very low, less than 0.01% relative to that of air, and it increases gradually from the air to the bottom c-Si substrate (
Figure S1
). Therefore, the effective refractive index of the c-Si TMW increases gradually from its top to the bottom part. The effective refractive index of the c-Si TMW is the average value of the refractive indices of air and c-Si according to the volume ratio at the interface between air and c-Si.
(32)
For efficient FDTD simulation, a perfectly matched layer (PML) boundary condition was applied along the
z
-axis, assuming that the thickness of the bottom c-Si substrate is infinite. Detailed simulation procedures can be found in the
Experimental Section
. The contour plot of the current density (
J
sc
) calculated through FDTD simulations (
Figure
1
b) quantitatively compares the light absorption of the c-Si TMW array according to the TMW length and interwire spacing. Theoretical
J
sc
was obtained by substituting the value of the simulated absorption of c-Si into
eq S1 in the Supporting Information
. By assuming that the internal quantum efficiency is 100%, irrespective of the wavelength, the term for the external quantum efficiency (EQE) was replaced by the absorption term. On the basis of
eq S1
, the theoretical maximum
J
sc
of a c-Si solar cell is estimated to be 43.37 mA/cm
2
, given that all the incident photons in the 300–1100 nm wavelength region are fully absorbed.
(33)

div.p:
Figure 1. (a) Schematic illustration of a tapered microwire (TMW) array employed in finite-difference time-domain simulations. The diameter of the TMW was fixed at 2 μm. (b) Calculated current density (
J
sc
) of the TMW array as a function of the interwire spacing and MW length. (c) Electric field intensity profiles (in log scale) for TMW arrays with an interwire spacing of 200 nm, 1 μm, and 2 μm. Electric field intensity profiles were obtained by integrating all the electric field intensities between 300 and 1100 nm with an interval of 100 nm.

div.div:
According to previous reports on the optical properties of MW structures, MWs of 20–70 μm length or greater are required to obtain a low reflectance (<5%) over a broad wavelength range.
(20,21,34)
However, on the basis of the results of the FDTD simulation presented in
Figure
1
b, we can draw three main conclusions: (1) in general, the theoretical
J
sc
increases with increasing TMW length; (2) however, there is a maximum limit to the theoretical
J
sc
estimated by increasing the wire length when the TMW spacing is wider than 1 μm; (3) the contour lines are generally horizontal rather than vertical, indicating that the wire spacing (
y
-axis) is the dominant factor that determines the theoretical
J
sc
value rather than the MW length (
x
-axis). Accordingly, light absorption can be enhanced more effectively by controlling the spacing between the TMWs rather than increasing the MW length. Moreover, longer TMWs would require a longer manufacturing time and increase the cost of solar cell fabrication. In other words, it is important to minimize the TMW length as well as maximize the light absorption, which could be achieved by tuning the interwire spacing. Furthermore, our simulation suggests the possibility of achieving a theoretical
J
sc
of ∼43 mA/cm
2
using TMW arrays with less than 10 μm long MWs and a 200 nm interwire spacing.

To account for the increase in the light absorption with a decrease in the TMW spacing, the electric field profiles between two TMWs separated by different distances are presented in
Figure
1
c. To enable an accurate comparison, 10 μm long TMWs with a spacing of 200 nm, 1.0 μm, and 2.0 μm were used for the simulation, and the electric field profiles were obtained by integrating all the electric field intensities between 300 and 1100 nm with an interval of 100 nm. Each electric field intensity profile is also presented in
Figures S2 and S3
. At the smallest interwire spacing (200 nm), light could not reach the bottom Si substrate. However, as the wire spacing is increased to 1.0 and 2.0 μm, light reaches the bottom Si substrate. This is also demonstrated in a time-dependent light propagation video provided in the
Supporting Information (Video S1)
. In the case of the specimen with the 200 nm spacing, most of the incident light is absorbed by the c-Si TMWs rather than being reflected from the structure. However, the behavior of the incident light changes with an increase in the spacing between the TMWs. When the spacing is increased to 1.0 and 2.0 μm, the light that is not absorbed by the structure is reflected by the bottom substrate and eventually escapes from the structure to air, resulting in optical loss.

The spacing effect can also be confirmed from the absorption profiles of the c-Si TMWs obtained by the FDTD power absorption simulation at different wavelengths (300–1100 nm with a 100 nm interval) according to their spacing (200 nm, 1 μm, and 2 μm, respectively) in
Figures S4 and S5
. In this simulation, 10 μm long TMWs were arranged with 200 nm, 1.0 μm, or 2.0 μm spacing. In the short wavelength region of <400 nm, c-Si has a high absorption coefficient, which leads to strong absorption at the surface of the TMWs.
(34)
Moreover, as the wavelength increases, the waveguide mode became more apparent. As the incident light is guided into the TMW structure, the light is absorbed by the core of the MW. Further, as the interwire spacing decreases, the overall light absorption by the wire increases. In addition, the absorption depth, which is directly related to the thickness of c-Si for complete light absorption, also decreases as the wire spacing decreases. Consequently, light absorption by c-Si can be maximized by decreasing the spacing between the TMWs. The simulated reflectance spectra in
Figure S6
also indicate a similar interaction between the incident light and c-Si TMW arrays upon changing the spacing between the TMWs. When the spacing of the 10 μm c-Si TMW arrays was set at 200 nm, the simulated reflectance approached zero in the 300–1100 nm wavelength range. However, the light reflection increased significantly in all wavelength regions when the spacing was set to 1.0 μm or more between TMWs of the same length. Thus, controlling the spacing between the TMWs at the nanometer scale (less than 200 nm) is an effective means of maximizing the light absorption by the c-Si TMW arrays while minimizing the occurrence of surface recombination.

For the experimental validation of the simulated results, we employed the microsphere-based soft lithography approach illustrated in
Figure
2
a to fabricate a series of c-Si TMW arrays with nanometer spacings. To fabricate c-Si MW arrays, a patterning process is required to form metal or photoresist microdot array on a c-Si wafer to serve as an etch mask. In general, c-Si MW structures are fabricated using photolithography as a patterning process.
(20,21,35−38)
However, as discussed in the introduction, conventional photolithography is not suitable for forming MW structures with nanometer spacings owing to the resolution issue.
(24)
Instead, soft lithography is a promising alternative to realize nanometer-scale patterns based on the self-assembly of polystyrene (PS) beads into a monolayer on the wafer surface.
(29)
A monolayer of PS beads (diameter, ∼2 μm) was formed on a c-Si wafer through a dip-coating method (
Figure S7
), which is a typical soft-lithography process.
(39)
The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the PS bead monolayers in
Figure
2
b show hexagonally close-packed PS beads with different spacings. To control the spacing between the PS beads on the c-Si wafer, the PS bead monolayer formed on the c-Si wafer was etched isotropically using an O
2
plasma-based RIE process as a post-treatment method. As the diameter of all the PS beads fixed on the c-Si substrate decreases isotropically during the RIE process, the spacing between the PS beads can be systematically controlled by changing the etching time. Further, the etch rate of the PS beads can be adjusted by tuning the O
2
flow rate and supplied power.
(40)
We confirmed that the spacing between the PS beads could be controlled well according to the etching time (
Figure
2
c). For example, as the etching time was increased to 390, 570, and 760 s, the spacing between the PS beads increased to 200, 300, and 400 nm, respectively. That is, the diameter of the PS beads decreased linearly with increasing etching time. The measured etch rate of the PS beads was 0.54 nm/s.

div.p: Figure 2. (a) Schematic illustration of the fabrication of c-Si TMW array via soft lithography. (b) Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of PS bead monolayers with varying spacing between the beads. (c) Diameter of the PS bead and bead-to-bead spacing as a function of etching time. Optical micrographs and SEM (inset) images of the (d) PS bead monolayer, (e) c-Si MW array, and (f) c-Si TMW array on a 4 in. c-Si wafer.

div.div:
According to the results of the FDTD simulation, we fabricated a c-Si TMW array with a 200 nm interwire spacing, which is expected to show maximized light absorption.
Figure
2
d displays the optical microscopy and SEM (inset) images of the PS bead monolayer formed on a 4 in. c-Si wafer. The SEM image (inset of
Figure
2
d) confirms the diameter and spacing of the PS beads to be 2 μm and 200 nm, respectively. The optimized PS bead monolayer was used as an etch mask for fabricating the MW array using the Bosch process. This deep RIE method involves cross-repeating cycles of etching gas (SF
6
) and passivation gas (C
4
F
8
) treatments, which facilitate an almost anisotropic c-Si etching. The c-Si MW array showed vivid colors owing to high light reflection from the flat top surface of the MWs, as shown in
Figure
2
e. Subsequently, the MW was converted to a tapered structure, whose diameter increases gradually from the top to bottom, using an isotropic wet-etching process. Interestingly, the optical image of the TMW array on the c-Si wafer appears black (
Figure
2
f), which indicates that there was hardly any reflection of light from its surface. The c-Si TMW array can significantly decrease the surface reflection of light of a broad wavelength range owing to the gradual change in the refractive index between the air at the top and Si at the bottom.
(21)
Therefore, it is important to modify the shape of the MWs as well as control the spacing between the MWs for maximizing the light absorption.

Figure
3
a shows the optical images of the TMW arrays with different spacings (2.0 μm, 1.0 μm, and 200 nm) formed on c-Si substrates. The TMW array with a 200 nm spacing was fabricated by soft lithography, as discussed in
Figure
2
, while the TMW arrays with 2.0 and 1.0 μm spacing were fabricated by a conventional photolithography process. The length of all the fabricated TMW arrays was fixed at 10 μm and was confirmed by SEM (see
Figure
3
b). The optical images of the TMW arrays with 2.0 and 1.0 μm spacings clearly exhibit colors owing to diffracted light, implying that a considerable amount of light was reflected from the front surface. This observation indicates that TMW arrays with micrometer-scale spacings cannot completely absorb the incident light, despite the optimized tapered shape of the MW. By contrast, the optical image of the TMW array with the 200 nm spacing is completely black color, confirming that the surface reflection of light is almost zero. Therefore, the c-Si TMW array with the 200 nm spacing is expected to have a higher
J
sc
than the TMW arrays with 2.0 and 1.0 μm spacings, as predicted by the FDTD simulation (
Figure
1
b).

div.p:
Figure 3. (a) Optical and (b) SEM images of c-Si TMW arrays with different spacings of 2.0 μm, 1.0 μm, and 200 nm. (c) Simulated (solid line) and experimental (dashed line) absorption spectra of the samples according to the TMW spacing: 200 nm (red), 1 μm (blue), and 2 μm (black). (d) Comparison of the simulated and experimentally measured
J
sc
of TMW arrays with different interwire spacings.

div.div:
Figure
3
c shows the absorption spectra of the fabricated c-Si TMW arrays displayed in
Figure
3
a. We compared the experimental absorption spectra of the fabricated c-Si TMW arrays with the absorption spectra simulated using identical physical dimensions. The absorption spectra of all the fabricated c-Si TMW arrays matched well with the simulated absorption spectra in the wavelength range of 300–1000 nm. However, for the c-Si TMW arrays with micrometer spacing (2.0 and 1.0 μm), an oscillation was observed in the simulated absorption spectra, showing a difference from the experimental spectra. The FDTD simulation uses a light source with high coherence, and thus the interference effect of the reflected light increases significantly during the simulation of a spectrum for a highly periodical structure.
(41)
This oscillation becomes significant as the spacing between the TMWs increases because the amount of light reflected from the bottom substrate increases as the interwire spacing increases. In addition, a significant difference (∼20%) was noted between the simulated and experimental absorption spectra in the NIR region (1000–1100 nm). This can be attributed to the PML boundary condition used for efficient FDTD simulation. In fact, c-Si has an indirect bandgap and hence has a low absorption coefficient at a wavelength near its bandgap. Therefore, the absorption capacity near the bandgap depends on the thickness of the bottom c-Si substrate. Because the PML boundary condition used in the FDTD simulation assumed that the thickness of the c-Si substrate is infinite, the NIR absorption of the fabricated structure on a 200 μm thick c-Si substrate differed from that of the simulated NIR absorption. Notably, the fabricated c-Si TMW array with a 200 nm spacing exhibited a very high absorption of >98.5% in the wavelength range of 300–1000 nm.

As shown in
Figure
3
d, the
J
sc
values calculated based on the experimental absorption spectra of the 10 μm long c-Si TMW arrays are 35.38, 41.72, and 42.90 mA/cm
2
, respectively, at 2.0 μm, 1.0 μm, and 200 nm spacings, which are comparable to those obtained by the FDTD simulation (the
J
sc
values calculated based on the simulated absorption spectra are 35.94, 41.85, and 43.31 mA/cm
2
for structures with 2.0 μm, 1.0 μm, and 200 nm spacings, respectively). The small difference between the results obtained by simulations and experiments can be attributed to two reasons: the oscillation effect mentioned earlier and the inconsistency of the absorption spectrum in the wavelength region of 1000–1100 nm, as discussed in relation to
Figure
3
c. Thus, we successfully realized a c-Si TMW array with nanometer-scale interwire spacing. Moreover, for the sample with a 200 nm spacing, both the
J
sc
values calculated using the theoretical and experimental absorption spectra are substantially close to the theoretical maximum
J
sc
of 43.37 mA/cm
2
.
(33)

To experimentally confirm the change in the photovoltaic performance according to the interwire spacing of the c-Si TMW arrays, three different solar cells were fabricated with the structure shown in
Figure
4
a. A radial junction was formed on the TMW array using a p-type emitter layer with a junction depth of ∼300 nm by a spin-on-dopant-based thermal doping process.
(21)
The depth of the p-type emitter layer was confirmed from the secondary-ion mass spectroscopy profile shown in
Figure S8
. This implies that a junction with a total thickness of 600 nm is formed radially at the surface of the MW. In c-Si TMW-based solar cells, top surface passivation is one of the critical factors that affect the photovoltaic performance because such cells have a significantly larger surface area than a planar device.
(17)
Consequently, surface recombination of charge carriers is significantly higher than that in a planar device. A 10 nm thick Al
2
O
3
layer was coated as a surface passivation layer on the front emitter layer to minimize the surface recombination. Further, a microgrid electrode was applied as a front electrode to effectively collect the photogenerated carriers.
(45,47)
This microgrid electrode had a spacing of 400 μm and width of 3 μm and thus occupied only 1.5% of the front area (
Figure S9
). Consequently, it minimized shading losses caused by front metal reflection. On the rear side of the solar cell, a back surface field (BSF) was formed with an n
+
doping layer. Additionally, the contact area between c-Si and the rear metal electrode was restricted to only 5%, while the remainder of the rear surface was passivated with a thermally grown SiO
2
layer to minimize the surface recombination, particularly for NIR light.

div.p:
Figure 4. (a) Schematic of the fabricated c-Si TMW solar cell. (b)
J
–
V
characteristics and (c) external quantum efficiency (EQE) of c-Si TMW solar cells with a spacing of 2.0 μm (black line), 1.0 μm (blue line), and 200 nm (red line). (d) Comparison of the PCE and current density achieved with the MW-based radial junction solar cell fabricated in this study with those of some previously reported devices.
(6,20,21,27,28,35,37,42−46)

Figure
4
b presents the
J
–
V
curves of the c-Si TMWs solar cells with different spacings of 2.0 μm, 1.0 μm, and 200 nm. The photovoltaic parameters are summarized in

To maximize the light absorption of c-Si TMW arrays, we optimized the structural parameters of TMW arrays through FDTD simulations. The length and interwire spacing of the TMWs were optimized for maximizing the light absorption. FDTD simulations suggested that the spacing between the TMW is the dominant factor that affects the light absorption rather than the MW length. In this work, we employed soft lithography to implement nanometer-scale spacing between the MWs and thus successfully obtained a TMW array with a spacing of 200 nm. Our TMW arrays exhibit an outstanding light-absorption property, reaching the Yablonovitch limit (
Figure S12
),
(50)
assuming perfect antireflection in the broad wavelength region (300–1100 nm). A c-Si TMW radial junction solar cell with 200 nm interwire spacing and 10 μm MW length exhibited an outstanding PCE of 20.5%, mainly owing to the high current density of 42.5 mA/cm
2
. To the best of our knowledge, this is the highest efficiency ever reported for a c-Si radial junction solar cell. This work indicates that controlling the spacing of TMW arrays using soft lithography is an effective strategy for fabricating highly efficient c-Si MW radial junction solar cells. Furthermore, the use of our proposed structure would be a promising strategy for improving the efficiency of thin-film c-Si solar cells. In general, a thin c-Si substrate with no surface structures (i.e., a planar substrate) exhibits a high surface reflection of over 40% over the entire wavelength range (300–1000 nm) and poor light absorption for wavelengths of >900 nm. To increase the light absorption of thin-film c-Si solar cells, a TMW structure was recently applied to thin c-Si; consequently, a high-efficiency (18.9%) thin-film c-Si solar cell was reported.
(21)
However, the spacing of the TMW array used in the previous study was 1 μm, which cannot fully absorb the incident light. By applying our proposed structure, it should be possible to develop a highly efficient flexible thin c-Si solar cell using TMW arrays by enhancing the light absorption.

FDTD simulations were carried out using the Lumerical FDTD software package. Commercial 3D Max (Autodesk) was used for the 3D modeling of TMW structures, and the exported STL files were imported to the FDTD program. The MW arrays were constructed using a 3D rectangular simulation region with periodic boundary conditions along the
x
and
y
axes. For constructing a hexagonal lattice of the TMW array, four TMWs were located at each corner (top view) of a square simulation region and a single TMW was placed at the center. The bottom Si substrate was placed beneath the TMW; infinite boundary conditions rendered as PML were applied along the
z
-axis. The lattice of the array was adjusted according to the interwire spacing. Palik material data provided by Lumerical were used for modeling the material as Si. The simulations were performed in the wavelength range of 300–1100 nm using a plane-wave light source.

div.h3: Fabrication of c-Si TMW Arrays via Soft Lithography
div.div:
Double-side-polished float zone n-type (100) c-Si wafers (resistivity of 1–5 Ω·cm, 300 μm thick) were used for the fabrication of TMW arrays. PS beads with a diameter of 2.1 μm were sprayed onto deionized water to form a monolayer. The PS bead monolayer was then transferred onto the Si substrate by the dip-coating method. To control the spacing between the beads in the PS bead monolayer, the diameter of the PS microspheres was decreased via RIE; the etching time was varied at a fixed O
2
flow of 100 sccm and power of 100 W. The c-Si substrate with the PS bead monolayer was etched by deep RIE (Tegal 200) at 1500 W source power, 100 W stage power, and 45 mTorr gas pressure under source gases of SF
6
(250 sccm) and C
4
F
8
(150 sccm). Finally, the TMWs were generated by immersing the c-Si substrates with MWs in a slow silicon etchant (RSE-100) for 15 s.

div.h3: Fabrication of c-Si TMW Solar Cells
div.div:
After the fabrication of the TMW arrays on the c-Si wafer (float zone n-type, resistivity of 1–5 Ω·cm, 300 μm thick), a BSF layer was formed in a tube furnace under a mixed atmosphere of O
2
(125 sccm) and N
2
(500 sccm) at 860 °C using the P509 dopant source. After the formation of the BSF layer, a 10 nm thick SiO
2
layer was thermally grown on the wafer in a furnace (KHD-306, KSM). This SiO
2
layer was removed from the front of the substrate with a BOE solution after the back side was protected with AZ4330 photoresist. Then, an additional SiO
2
layer (200 nm in thickness) was deposited on the rear side of the wafer via plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PEH-600). Then, an emitter layer was formed on the top surface of the wafer under N
2
(500 sccm) at 880 °C using the B155 dopant source. A 10 nm Al
2
O
3
passivation layer was deposited on the front side of the wafer via atomic layer deposition (Lucida D100, NCD) and annealed under 500 sccm of a mixed gas of Ar/H
2
(96:4) at 500 °C. Patterns for the metal grid electrodes and localized back contact surface were lithographically defined on the front and rear sides of the samples, respectively, using AZ4330 photoresist. To finish the electrode fabrication, the substrates were dipped in a BOE solution, and 600 nm thick Al (front) and 600 nm thick Ag (rear) films were deposited on both sides of the wafer via thermal evaporation. The active area of the fabricated solar cells was set as 1 cm
2
.

div.h3: Characterization of the Fabricated c-Si TMW Solar Cells
div.div: The photovoltaic properties of the fabricated solar cells were evaluated using an Oriel Sol3A class AAA solar simulator (Newport) under AM 1.5G illumination. The incident flux was measured using a calibrated power meter and verified using an NREL-calibrated solar cell (PV Measurements, Inc.). EQE was evaluated in the 300–1100 nm wavelength range under the excitation of a Xe light source coupled with a monochromator. Optical reflection was investigated in the same wavelength range using a UV–vis/NIR spectrophotometer (Cary 5000, Agilent) equipped with a 110 mm integrating sphere to estimate the total light (diffuse and specular) reflected from the samples.

With a global market share of about 90%, cryst. silicon is by far the most important photovoltaic technol. today. This article reviews the dynamic field of cryst. silicon photovoltaics from a device-engineering perspective. First, it discusses key factors responsible for the success of the classic dopant-diffused silicon homojunction solar cell. A salient characteristic of solar cells is their ability to subject photo-generated electrons and holes to pathways of asym. cond.-'assisting' them towards their resp. contacts. All com. available cryst. silicon (c-Si) solar cells achieve this by making use of doping in either near-surface regions or overlying silicon-based films. Despite being commonplace, this approach is hindered by several optoelectronic losses and technol. limitations specific to doped silicon. A progressive approach to circumvent these issues involves the replacement of doped-silicon contacts with alternative materials which can also form 'carrier-selective' interfaces on c-Si. Here we successfully develop and implement dopant-free electron and hole carrier-selective heterocontacts using alkali metal fluorides and metal oxides, resp., in combination with passivating intrinsic amorphous silicon interlayers, resulting in power conversion efficiencies approaching 20%. Furthermore, the simplified architectures inherent to this approach allow cell fabrication in only seven low-temp. (≤200°C), lithog.-free steps. This is a marked improvement on conventional doped-silicon high-efficiency processes, and highlights potential improvements on both sides of the cost-to-performance ratio for c-Si photovoltaics.

In the current work, we report a new paradigm for light trapping, that is light trapping based on arrays of subwavelength nonimaging light concentrators (NLCs). We numerically show that silicon NLC arrays provide >75% broadband absorption enhancement of the solar radiation compared with that of optimized nanopillar arrays.
